0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Liver transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: 20 mg IV within 2 hr before transplant surgery; then another 20 mg IV dose day 4 post-op
  • Renal transplant rejection, in combination with cyclosporine and corticosteroids; Prophylaxis: IV; 20 mg IV within 2 hr before transplant surgery; then another 20 mg IV dose day 4 post-op

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Renal transplant rejection, in combination with cyclosporine and corticosteroids; Prophylaxis: IV; (weight less than 35 kg) 2 doses of 10 mg each; first dose within 2 hr prior to transplant, second dose 4 days after transplant; withhold second dose if complications occur
  • Renal transplant rejection, in combination with cyclosporine and corticosteroids; Prophylaxis: IV; (weight 35 kg or more) 2 doses of 20 mg each; first dose within 2 hr prior to transplant, second dose 4 days after transplant; withhold second dose if complications occur

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Renal transplant rejection, in combination with cyclosporine and corticosteroids; Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Graft versus host disease
  • Liver transplant rejection; Prophylaxis

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Intravenous (Powder for Solution)
Only physicians experienced in immunosuppression therapy and management of organ transplantation patients should prescribe basiliximab and they should have complete information requisite for the follow-up of the patient. Patients receiving the drug should be managed in facilities equipped and staffed with adequate laboratory and supportive medical resources.

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• severe acute hypersensitivity reactions have occurred with initial exposure and/or following re-exposure
  • history of untoward events related to use of basiliximab, daclizumab, or other monoclonal antibodies
  • basiliximab is indicated only in conjunction with other immunosuppressants (cyclosporine corticosteroids); all relative/absolute contraindications for these latter agents also apply whenever basiliximab is administered
  • elderly patients

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain, Vomiting
  • Neurologic:Asthenia, Dizziness, Insomnia
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Edema, Hypertension
  • Hematologic:Anemia
  • Immunologic:Allergic reaction, acute
  • Renal:Dysuria
  • Respiratory:Candidiasis (frequent), Cough (frequent), Dyspnea (frequent)
  • Other:Cytomegalovirus infection, Fever (frequent)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Basiliximab is an interleukin-2 (IL-2) receptor antagonist that binds to the alpha subunit of the IL-2 receptor complex and inhibits IL-2 binding . By inhibiting IL-2 binding, IL-2-mediated activation of lymphocytes is prevented, and the response of the immune system to antigens is impaired .

1.title: Distribution
1.mono: Systemic: Vd: 8.6 plus or minus 4.1 L Adults; 10.1 plus or minus 7.6 L Adolescents; 5.2 plus or minus 2.8 L Children

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono: Systemic: 7.2 plus or minus 3.2 d Adults; 7.2 plus or minus 3.6 d Adolescents; 11.5 plus or minus 6.3 d Children

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • for central or peripheral intravenous use only
  • to reconstitute, add 2.5 or 5 mL Sterile Water for Injection to the 10 mg and 20 mg vials, respectively
  • use solution within 4 h after reconstitution at room temp or 24 h under refrigeration
  • (bolus) reconstituted solution is isotonic and may be given as an IV bolus injection
  • (infusion) solution may be further diluted to 25-50 mL NS or D5W and infused over 20-30 min

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• signs/symptoms of rejection
  • CBC
  • renal function
  • signs/symptoms of infection
  • acute hypersensitivity reactions (including anaphylaxis)

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause abdominal pain, vomiting, asthenia, dizziness, insomnia, edema, anemia, or dysuria.
  • Drug may frequently cause candidiasis, cough, dyspnea, or fever.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of infection or organ rejection.
